children.comment: Ok but you might still need to examine inducement, and see if the infringement is done at UO's direction
It is willful in the case of bambam but UO just buys cloth or completed pieces from bambam, in theory, and is less likely to be willful.

children.author: UncreativeURL
children.comment: The creator can just sue both parties.
Exactly. That's why it's infringement; both parties are using someone's original design to make a profit.
They make a profit from selling the design. They aren't the ones who "created" it, though. Doubly so since bambam actually sells it too.
I would wager that both parties are at fault, since UO still makes a profit off the design.
It isn't UO, they are just the seller. www.bambamcloth.com is the actual source of the infringement.
Don't think so. UO has flagrantly violated fair use rules; it seems like a pretty cut and dried case of copyright infringement.

children.author: UncreativeURL
children.comment: Either "large quantity" or "exact design" would have the same weight.
It isn't "a large quantity" it is "the exact design". They'll ruin the artist, though. Either with lawyers or appeals.
Also, since the nature of the original design is creative, and since UO used a large quantity of that design, OP should win in court.
...to make money, and since this has an impact on the market for the original (OP's design), OP has a case (2/?)
Yup. Might be hard for OP to prove likelihood of access, but UO does show substantial similarity to OP's work. Since UO's purpose is (1/?)
Even if that is the case, isn't this blatant copyright infringement?
non-clothing items, like tote bags and clocks. Not saying she shouldn't win, but UO will definitely be able to make an argument. 2/2
If you notice, she doesn't use this design on clothing. OP screen prints it into a diamond shape on shirts, and uses the full design for 1/2
